lines.text: But don't you think he'd be good for Happy? He's an outdoor man.
So's the guy who collects my garbage.
You won't drink too much in Vermont, will you Mr. Law?
Only the heady wine air that has no dregs.
'Cause you're crazy enough without drinking.
Talk about scope sweep. Boy, what a set up!
What a love story!
A great love story.
A baby brings them together, splits them apart, brings them together again,
Boy meets girl.
Boy loses girl.
Boy gets girl.
Boy, I think you got something. Let's try it out on B.K. while it's hot.
Wait a minute. You can't act with a baby. They'll steal every scene.
Are you selling motherhood short?
Come on!
Come on!
Don't make fun of me.
Fun? Well, I've never been so touched in all my life. Susie, I feel purified.
Susie, can we be Godfathers?
Do you mean it?
"Benson and Law Godfathering In June".
I've got Larry Toms waiting in your office to hear your story. Come on.
We haven't got any stories.
Tell him one anyway.
Okay. Once there was a fairy princess who lived in a broken down castle, on a broken down river, with a broken down aunt. In fact, she was a broken down princess.
I was a promising young novelist. Almost won the Pulitzer Prize in nineteen thirty, and now in nineteen thirty eight, I'm writing dialogue for a horse.
Larry! Larry, take a breath. The boy's mean no harm. Exhale.
I smell carbon exhaust.
One more crack...
"Tiger Tamer". There it is, right there in the corner. "Tiger Tamer" by J. Carlyle Benson and Robert Law.
That's a forgery! Benson, we've been framed.
Why you...
This is the last prank you boys will ever play.
I think you're very intelligent.
Oh, I'm intelligent, but I don't know anything.
And Simmons, get me some trumpets that sound like trumpets.
Um, you sure you don't mean trombones, Mr Friday?
I mean trumpets. I'm no musician, but I know what I mean. Trumpets... that slide!
